nodes.text: Conventional ex-ante cost-benefit analysis assumes cost and benefit estimates are accurate and unbiased, and thus can improve public resource allocation; we hypothesize this assumption is false and that cost-benefit analysis as practiced is misleading

Method: assembled the largest dataset of its kind with 2,062 public investment projects across eight investment types, 104 countries, 1927-2013; cost overrun measured as actual/estimated cost, benefit overrun as actual/estimated benefit, using construction costs and first-year benefits as proxies

Evidence: cost overrun data show systematic bias and heavy right tails; overall average cost overrun about 1.39 to 1.43 (i.e., 39â€“43 percent higher than estimated) with extreme skewness and kurtosis and p < 0.0001

Evidence: benefit overrun data show systematic bias toward shortfalls for many investment types; weighted average benefit overrun about 0.94 (6 percent shortfall) and several modes like BRT and rail show large shortfalls (BRT 0.42, rail 0.66); distributions are skewed and fat tailed with p < 0.001

Result: cost underestimation and benefit overestimation compound for the average investment ('double whammy'), with investment types that have large cost overruns tending to have large benefit shortfalls, rejected hypothesis that errors cancel (Mann-Whitney p < 0.0001)
Result: conventional ex-ante benefit-cost ratios are overestimated by roughly 50 to 200 percent depending on investment type, making ex-ante cost-benefit analysis highly misleading

Evidence and robustness: results hold across conventional and Bayesian analyses, across samples including the 327-investment subsample with both cost and benefit data, across geographies and time, indicating a universal pattern

Claim: behavioral mechanisms explain systematic bias better than technical explanations; root causes are optimism bias, planning fallacy, overconfidence, and strategic misrepresentation leading planners to underestimate schedules, geology, prices, scope changes and mitigation failure

Conclusion: because estimates are systematically biased and compound, cost-benefit analysis as currently practiced can cause resource misallocation and approve projects that should not be started, sometimes harming national economies

Claim: correcting the cost-benefit fallacy requires behavioral de-biasing methods, accountability incentives for forecasters, independent audits, and adapting cost-benefit practice to democratic decision making

Method/Claim: reference class forecasting and taking the outside view using empirical distributional data provides a systematic, statistical de-biasing method and has been validated and adopted in some countries
Claim: introducing skin-in-the-game and legal or financial accountability for forecasters will align incentives and reduce deliberate or negligent misrepresentation
Claim: independent, politically insulated audits are necessary to ensure de-biasing methods and incentives function and to allow external transparency and scrutiny
Claim: cost-benefit analysis must be integrated into messy democratic decision processes rather than used as top-down technocratic sole determinant, combining expert analysis with public concerns

Limitation/Assumption: data availability constrained measurement to proxies (construction costs and first-year benefits) and only 327 projects had both cost and benefit data; sample inclusion based on available reliable documents may produce conservative bias underestimating true population cost overruns
